The 2012 D&D Experience convention (January 26 - January 29) was held in Fort Wayne, Indiana, during which hundreds of convention goers got a first look at the concepts behind D&D 5th edition.
document_data.mainbody: n July 15, 2014, the ''[[Dungeons & Dragons Starter Set]]'' was released in a box with booklets for the DM and the players, pregenerated characters, six dice, and an adventure for levels 1–5. This was quickly followed by the full ''[[Player's Handbook 5th edition|Player's Handbook]]'' in August, the ''[[Monster Manual 5th edition|Monster Manual]]'' in September, and the ''[[Dungeon Master's Guide 5th edition|Dungeon Master's Guide]]'' in December of that year. The new rules reverted almost all the 4th edition changes to the game mechanics and now resembled an improved and simplified 3.5 system.
document_data.Editions of ''Dungeons & Dragons'':
Since the original release in 1974, several editions of ''Dungeons & Dragons'' have been published,[[wikipedia:Editions of Dungeons & Dragons|Editions of Dungeons & Dragons]] sometimes with major changes to the rulebooks. {| class="wikitable dndtable" |+ Dungeons & Dragons Version History, noting key rule publications |- ! style="width:4em;" | YEAR ! colspan="2" | GAME |- ! 1974 | class="dnd1974" colspan="2" | '''''Dungeons & Dragons''''' (original white box edition with three booklets) ''Men & Magic'' • ''Monsters & Treasure'' • ''The Underworld & Wilderness Adventures'' |- ! 1977 | class="dnd1977-1" | '''''Advanced Dungeons & Dragons''''' (1st Edition) ''Monster Manual'' (December) | class="dnd1977-2" rowspan="3" | '''''Dungeons & Dragons''''' (2nd version) ''Basic Set'' (blue box) (levels 1–3) |- ! 1978 | class="dnd1977-1" | ''Players Handbook'' (June) |- ! 1979 | class="dnd1977-1" rowspan="2" | ''Dungeon Masters Guide'' (August) Core rulebooks complete |- ! 1981 | class="dnd1981" | '''''Dungeons & Dragons''''' (3rd version) ''Basic Set'' (magenta box)
''Expert Set'' (light blue box) (levels 4–14) |- ! 1983 | class="dnd1977-1" rowspan="2" | Core rulebooks reprinted with
new cover art and orange spines | class="dnd1983" | '''''Dungeons & Dragons''''' (4th version) ''Basic Set'' (red box)
''Expert Set'' (blue box)
''Companion Set'' (teal box, levels 15–25) |- ! 1984 | class="dnd1983" | ''Master Set'' (black box, levels 26–36) |- ! 1985 | class="dnd1977-1" | ''Unearthed Arcana'' (a fourth "core" rulebook)
  | class="dnd1983" rowspan="2" | ''Immortals Set'' (gold box, levels 36+) |- ! 1989 | class="dnd1989" rowspan="3" | '''''Advanced Dungeons & Dragons'' 2nd edition''' ''Player's Handbook''
''Dungeon Master's Guide''
''Monstrous Compendium'' Replaces ''Monster Manual'' |- ! 1991 | class="dnd1991" | '''''Dungeons & Dragons''''' (5th version) ''Rules Cyclopedia'' (levels 1–36) |- ! 1992 | class="dnd1991" rowspan="4" | ''Wrath of the Immortals'' (levels 36+) |- ! 1993 | class="dnd1989" | ''Monstrous Manual'' Replaces ''Monstrous Compendium'' |- ! rowspan="2" | 1995 | class="dnd1989" | '''''Advanced Dungeons & Dragons'' 2nd edition''' revised ''Player's Handbook''
''Dungeon Master Guide'' |- | class="dnd1989" | '''''Advanced Dungeons & Dragons'' 2nd edition''' revised ''Player's Options''
''DM Options'' |- ! 2000 | class="dnd2000" colspan="2"| '''''Dungeons & Dragons'' 3rd edition''' (three ''Core'' rulebooks) ''Player's Handbook'' • ''Dungeon Master's Guide'' • ''Monster Manual'' |- ! 2003 | class="dnd2000" colspan="2"| '''''Dungeons & Dragons'' 3rd edition revised''' (v3.5) Revised editions of the core rulebooks (compatible with 3.0 via errata) |- ! 2008 | class="dnd2008" colspan="2"| '''''Dungeons & Dragons'' 4th edition''' (three ''Core'' rulebooks) ''Player's Handbook'' • ''Monster Manual'' • ''Dungeon Master's Guide'' |- ! 2009 | class="dnd2008" colspan="2"| ''Player's Handbook 2'' • ''Monster Manual 2'' • ''Dungeon Master's Guide 2'' |- ! 2010 | class="dnd2008" | ''Player's Handbook 3'' • ''Monster Manual 3'' | class="dnd2010" | '''''Dungeons & Dragons''''' '''Essentials''' ''Fantasy Roleplaying Game'' (levels 1-2)
''Rules Compendium'' • ''Dungeon Master's Kit'' • ''Monster Vault'' (levels 1-30)
''Heroes of the Fallen Lands'' • ''Heroes of the Forgotten Kingdoms'' |- !2012 | class="dnd2012" colspan="2"| '''''Dungeons & Dragons'' 5th edition''' (announced) |- !2014 | class="dnd2012" colspan="2"| '''''Dungeons & Dragons'' 5th edition''' (three ''Core'' rulebooks and boxed Starter Set) ''Starter Set'' • ''Player's Handbook'' • ''Monster Manual'' • ''Dungeon Master's Guide'' |} Several revisions of ''Dungeons & Dragons'' have been released. The first edition (January 1974) was just called ''Dungeons & Dragons'', now referred to as [[Original Dungeons & Dragons|original ''Dungeons & Dragons'']]. Built on ''[[Chainmail]]'' fantasy rules, it consists in a box set with three booklets, ''[[Men & Magic]]'', ''[[Monsters & Treasure]]'', ''[[The Underworld & Wilderness Adventures]]'', and five supplements, ''Greyhawk'', ''Blackmoor'', ''Eldritch Wizardry'', ''Gods, Demi-Gods, & Heroes'' and ''Swords & Spells''. In 1977 was introduced the ''[[Dungeons & Dragons Basic Set]]'', followed by ''Dungeons & Dragons Expert Set'' and several supplementary books. The basic set dealt with characters from levels 1-3; as characters got stronger, players had to move to the more advanced rulebooks to manage their characters. In 1978 was published '''Advanced Dungeons & Dragons''' ('''AD&D'''), with its three "core rulebooks", ''[[Player's Handbook]]'', ''[[Dungeon Master's Guide]]'' and ''[[Monster Manual]]'', but this was a new ruleset that was unrelated to the original rules. A second edition of AD&D was released in 1989, which is still popular today. [[File:Players Handbook 3rd.jpg|thumb|The ''Dungeons & Dragons'' 3rd Edition ''[[Player's Handbook]]'']] After [[Wizards of the Coast]] bought the rights to ''Dungeons & Dragons'', a more streamlined version of the game was released in 2000, called ''Dungeons & Dragons'' 3rd Edition. Most die-rolls were done with a 20 sided [[dice|die]], instead of different types of multi-sided dice. The 3rd edition rules were eventually revised in 2003, and version 3.5 was released. ''Dungeons & Dragons'' 4th edition was published in June 2008 with completely revamped gameplay mechanics, combat rules, and magic system. This shakeup of tradition received mixed reviews. On January 9, 2012, [[Wizards of the Coast]] announced that they had begun work on ''Dungeons & Dragons'' 5th edition[http://www.wizards.com/DnD/Article.aspx?x=dnd/4ll/20120109 Charting the Course for D&D: Your Voice, Your Game]. The 2012 D&D Experience convention (January 26 - January 29) was held in Fort Wayne, Indiana, during which hundreds of convention goers got a first look at the concepts behind D&D 5th edition. On July 15, 2014, the ''[[Dungeons & Dragons Starter Set]]'' was released in a box with booklets for the DM and the players, pregenerated characters, six dice, and an adventure for levels 1–5. This was quickly followed by the full ''[[Player's Handbook 5th edition|Player's Handbook]]'' in August, the ''[[Monster Manual 5th edition|Monster Manual]]'' in September, and the ''[[Dungeon Master's Guide 5th edition|Dungeon Master's Guide]]'' in December of that year. The new rules reverted almost all the 4th edition changes to the game mechanics and now resembled an improved and simplified 3.5 system.
document_data.Common Accessories and Tools:
#'''Dice'''
#* '''Polyhedral Dice''': Standard sets typically include a d4, d6, d8, d10, d12, and d20. These are essential for determining outcomes of actions and events in the game.
#'''Character Sheets'''
#* '''Character Sheets''': Detailed documents that track a character's abilities, skills, equipment, and progress throughout the campaign.
#'''Miniatures'''
#* '''Miniatures''': Small figures representing characters, monsters, and NPCs (non-player characters). They are often used on a battle grid to visualize combat scenarios.
#'''Battle Maps'''
#* '''Battle Maps''': Gridded maps where miniatures can be placed to represent the game environment. These can be pre-made or drawn by the Dungeon Master (DM).
#'''Dungeon Master Screen'''
#* '''DM Screen''': A foldable screen that allows the DM to hide their notes, maps, and dice rolls from the players. It often includes useful reference charts on the inside.
#'''Rulebooks'''
#* '''Player's Handbook (PHB)''': The main guide for players, containing rules, classes, races, spells, and equipment.
#* '''Dungeon Master's Guide (DMG)''': A guide for DMs, providing tips, additional rules, and world-building advice.
#* '''Monster Manual''': A compendium of creatures and monsters that players may encounter in their adventures.
#'''Tokens and Markers'''
#* '''Condition Tokens''': Used to mark status effects like poisoned, stunned, or grappled on characters or monsters.
#* '''Initiative Trackers''': Tools to keep track of the order of turns during combat.
#'''Terrain Pieces'''
#* '''Terrain Pieces''': Three-dimensional pieces representing various environments like forests, mountains, buildings, and dungeons. These add depth to the battle maps.
#'''Spell Cards'''
#* '''Spell Cards''': Decks of cards that list spells and their effects, making it easier for spellcasters to manage their abilities.
#'''Notebooks and Journals'''
#* '''Notebooks and Journals''': Used by players and the DM to keep notes on the campaign, character backstories, and plot developments.
#'''Apps and Digital Tools'''
#* '''Digital Character Builders''': Apps and websites that help players create and manage their characters.
#* '''Virtual Tabletop (VTT) Platforms''': Online platforms like Roll20 and Fantasy Grounds that allow for remote play with digital maps, tokens, and dice rolling.
#'''Props and Costumes'''
#* '''Props''': Physical items like fake coins, maps, or artifacts that can be used to enhance the storytelling experience.
#* '''Costumes''': Some players and DMs dress up as their characters or NPCs to add an extra layer of immersion.
